titlestmt.title: PCT 21: A Poor Assiniboine Becomes Chief
titlestmt.author: Adam Sakewew

bibl.title: Plains Cree Texts
bibl.series: Publications of the American Ethnological Society, Volume XVI

encodingdesc.p: This electronic document is oriented more toward representing those features that seem most likely to be relevant for grammatical analyses, rather than toward faithfully representing all the information available in the book.

list.item: 2014 06 10; KR; UTF-8, paragraph and sentence numbering, smart-quotes in English translations

body.head: PCT 21 - A poor Assiniboine becomes chief

p.seg: kîtahtawê opwâsimowak mihcêtiwak ; mînah mikiwâhpah mihcêtinwah . Once upon a time there were many Assiniboine Sioux; and there were many tents.
pêyak opwâsîmôw oskinîkiw mistahi kitimâkisiw . One Assiniboine, a young man, was very poor.
nam âwiyah owâhkomâkanah pimâtisiyiwah . None of his kinsfolk were living.
tâpwê nikitimâkisin , itêyihtam . “Truly I am wretched,” he thought.
êkwah wîwah , nôtokêsiwah kêkâc , kakwêcimêw : Then he asked his wife, who was nearly an old woman:

seg.q: awiyak cî kiwâhkomâkan pimâtisiw , kôhtâwiy kikâwiy kisîm kistês kimis ?
seg.gloss: “Are any of your kinsfolk alive, your father, your mother, your younger brother or sister, your elder brother, your elder sister?

p.seg: nam âwiyak cî pimâtisiw ? itêw . Is none of them alive?” he asked her.

êkwah omis îtik :
mitoni nam âwiyak . She answered him, “They are all gone.”

seg.gloss: “Then truly we are pitiable.
Take heart and work.

seg.q: niya mînah nik-âhkamêyimon , ôtah kâ-wîkihkêmoyahk kit-âtoskawâyahkok ta-pamihâyahkok , ôma itah kâ-wîkihkêmoyahk .
seg.gloss: I too shall take courage, and we shall work for the people here among whom we dwell.”

p.seg: êhag , itik . “Yes,” she answered him.
êh-piponiyik êkwah atoskêwak . In winter then they worked.
êh-miyoskamik êh-âhtokêwiht , êkwah papâmohtêw . In spring, when his people moved camp, he walked about.
matokahpihk pôtê miskam : mîkwanah êkwah pîwâpiskwah . In an abandoned lodge he found something: some feathers and some pieces of metal.
êkwah kîwêhtatâw ; owîkimâkanah miyêw . He took the things home and gave them to his wife.
nah ôhi kanawêyihtah , itêw . “Take these things and save them up,” he told her. CHECK nah
êkwah manimisâskwatwêw ; ahcâpiyah mînah osîhêw ; nîsitanaw niyânanosâp osîhtâw acosisah . Then he gathered spruce-wood; he made a bow and twenty-five arrows.
êkwah astâwêw . Then he put feathers on the arrows.
kîsihtâw kahkiyaw . He completed it all.
êkwah pîhtatwânah kaskikwâtêw . Then he sewed a quiver.
êkwah ispatinâhk itohtêw , ê-wîhkwêstêyikih mîkiwahpah ê-kitâpahtahk . Then he went to the top of a hill and looked at the lodges which stood in a circle.
wâpahtam mîkiwâhp pîhtêyis êh-cimatêyik . He saw a single lodge which stood in the center.

itêyihtam ,
wêyôtisiw nâhah . He thought, “That man is rich.

seg.gloss: Suppose I go ask him;

p.seg: nka-ntaw-âtâmâw atimwah pêyak ôh ôhci nîpisisah , itêyihtam . I shall buy a dog from him with these arrows,” he thought.
itohtêw êh-otâkosiniyik , mihcêt êh-wâpamât atimwah , otâpânâskwah , atim-ôtâpânâskwah . He went there in the evening, and saw a great many dogs and sleds, dog-sleds.
êkwah êh-pîhtokêt , pôtih apiyiwa nâpêwa . When he entered the lodge, there sat a man.
tawâw , oskinîkiw , itik ; “Come in, young man,” said the other to him;

seg.gloss: “Come, let him eat.”

p.seg: asamâw . He was given to eat.
ê-kîsi-mîcisot , miyêw . When he had finished his meal, he gave the things to the other.

seg.q:
ôh ôhci kâ-pêy-itohtêyân acosisah ,
mâskôc pêyak miyicih , êh-itêyihtamân , k-oh-pîhtokêyân .
seg.gloss: “I have come here on account of these arrows, thinking perhaps he would give me a puppy;' that is why I have come to our tent.”
“Yes, I shall give you some.”

p.seg: têpakohp ihtasiyiwah . There were seven of them.

seg.gloss: “These puppies have already opened their eyes;

seg.q: êwakonik kimiyitin ; êkwah okâwiwâwa , acimosisak okâwîwâwah .
seg.gloss: I give you these; also the dam, the puppies' mother.
I thank you for having come and given me these things.”

p.seg: êkwah iskwêwak postamohêwak kiskânakwah ôhi k-âtâwêwiht . Then the women harnessed the female that had been sold.
kêkâ-tipiskâyiw âsay . It was already close to night.
kîwêhtahêw ; nayômêw acimosisah kahkiyaw . He took them home, carrying all the puppies.
pimitisahok ôhih kiskânakwah . The bitch ran behind him.

owîkimâkanah kitotêw ,
pê-wayawî ! He called to his wife, “Come out!”
wayawîw aw îskwêw . She came out of the lodge.

seg.gloss: “Tie her up.
Let her suckle these puppies of hers.”

p.seg: sakahpitêw . asamêw ôh âtimwah . She tied her up and fed her.
ohpikihêw otawâsimisah . The dog brought up its young.
âsay mînah kotakah kîskikaham misâskwatwah . Then again he cut some spruce-sticks.
kêyâpic êko-tahto , nîsitanaw niyânanosâp âsay min ôsihtâw . Again the same number, twenty-five, he made.
êh-kîsihtât , âsay minah ispatinâhk itohtêw . âsay minah kitâpahtam mîkiwahpah . When he had finished them, again he went to the hill-top and looked down at the tents.
nêkih mihcêtiwak êh-atoskêcik iskwêwak , itêyihtam ; “Down there are many women at work,” he thought;
êkotê nika-kiwokân , itêyihtam awah kâ-kitimâkisit opwâsîmôw . “There I shall visit,” thought the poor Stony.
kiyokêw êh-otâkosiniyik , êh-pimiwitât ôhi kâ-kîh-osîhtât acosisah . He made his visit at dusk, carrying along the arrows he had made.

ê-takohtêt mîkiwâhpihk ,
tawâw , itik ôhi nâpêwah . When he came to the tent, “Come in,” said the man to him.
pîhtokêw ; âsay mînah asamâw . He entered; this time too he was given food.

ê-kîsi-mîcisot ,
hâw , oskinîkiw ! nama wîhkâc kikiwokân . When he had eaten, “Now, young man, it is not your habit to go a-visiting.

seg.gloss: No doubt you have called here with something in mind.”
“It is that I have come to trade you these things which I am carrying with me, if you have the trade.

seg.q:
ayâwak iskwêwak mihkihkwanah mâtahikan cîkahikan kiskiman môhkomân , êh-itêyihtamân ,
mahtih nka-ntaw-âtâmâw , k-êtêyihtamân .
seg.gloss: 'The women have hide-flatteners, hide-scrapers, hatchets, files, and knives,' was my thought; 'Suppose I go buy them from him,' was my thought.”

p.seg: âhag , ihtakonwah , itik ôhi nâpêwah . “Yes, these things are here,” said the man to him.
kahkiyaw miyik tahto kâ-pêw-atâmât . He gave him all the things he had come to buy.
kîwêhtatâw wîkiwâhk . êkwah miyêw owîkimâkanah . He took them home and gave them to his wife.

seg.gloss: “Here, take these things; do you keep them; put them away and take care of them;

p.seg: osâm mistahê kikitimâkisinânaw , itêw owîkimâkanah . we are altogether too destitute,” said he to his wife.

êhag , itik ,
kitatamihin , itik owîkimâkanah . “Yes,” his wife answered him; “Thank you.”
âsay mînah otinam misâskwatwah ; âsay minah nîsitanaw niyânanosâp osîhtâw . Again he took some spruce-sticks; again he made twenty-five.
kîsihtâw . He finished them.
âsay minah êw-otâkosiniyik ê-wîhkwêstêyikih mîkiwâhpah kitâpahtam : Again at nightfall he looked at the tents standing in a circle.
pôtih pîhtêyisk cimatêyiw mîkiwâhp . There in the center stood a lodge.

itêyihtam :
nâhah okimâw manitôwiw ; nihtâ-nanâtawihiwêw , itêyihtam . He thought: “Yonder chief has spirit-power; he is a great healer.”
itohtêw ; êh-otâkosiniyik pîhtokêw . He went there; at nightfall he entered.
tawâw , itâw . “Come in,” he was told.
âsay minah asamâw . Again he was given food.
êh-itâpit askotâskopisonihk , pôtih wâpahtam pâskisikanah nistoh . When he looked at the wooden beams along the wall, there he saw three guns.
asamâw . He was given food.

êh-kîsi-mîcisot , miyâw pâskisikan pêyak , êh-atâwêt ôh ôhci acosisah , êkwah kaskitêw pîhcipihkwânah ê-sâkaskinêyit , êkwah môsasiniyah nîsitanaw , êkwah cahkisêhikanah nîso , êkwah kêtahikanah nîso . When he had eaten, he was given a gun, which he bought with those arrows, also some gun-powder, a powder-horn full of it, twenty bullets, two flints, and two ramrods.
kitatamihin , oskinîkiw , ôhih kâ-miyiyin , itêw . “I thank you, young man, for giving me these,” he said to him.
kîwêw . He went home.
êkosi kanawêyihtah , itêw owîkimâkanah . “So do you save these things,” he told his wife.

âsay minah osîhtâw acosisah nîsitanaw ,
êyôkonih nik-âyân , êh-itêyihtahk . Again he made twenty arrows, “These I shall keep,” being his plan.
kîsihtâw . He finished them.
âsay mitonih misikitiwak . they were already quite big.
êkwah aw îskwêw nakayâhêw . The woman broke them to harness.
pâ-pîmâkâmêpitêw ôh âcimosisah . She hitched up those young dogs.
êkwah kêkâc pipon . êkwah mitoni kisin . Then it was nearly winter, and very cold.
kêkâc êh-pipohk , paskêpiciwak êh-nîsicik owîkimâkanah awa kâ-kitimâkisit . When it was nearly winter, the two, the poor man and his wife, moved camp away from the others.

sakâw otihtam êh-ihkatawayik , wâsakâm ê-sakâyik , mihtah êh-micêniyikih , mînah mostoswah êh-mihcêtiyit . He came to a wood with an open space in the middle with woods all round, where there was plenty of fuel and where the buffalos were many.
nipahêw pêyak mostoswah . He killed a buffalo.
êkwah osîhtâw wîkih , mîkiwâhp , mihtikowâhp ê-misâyik . Then he built his dwelling, a large wooden house.
êkwah kahkiyaw otinam wiyâs . He took all the meat.
êkwah tahto-kîsikâw mâcîw ; tahto-kîsikâw minahôw . Then every day he hunted; every day he made a killing.
atimwah âpacihêwak ayênâniw ; kahkiyaw otinamwak wiyâs . They used the eight dogs; they took all the meat.

mînah wanîhikêw mistiko-wanîhikanah , mahîhkanah êh-nôcihât , nanâtohk atâwâkanah ê-nipahât wanihikanihk . Also he trapped with wooden traps, trying for wolves, and killed all kinds of fur-bearing beasts in his traps.
pêyak kîsikâw âskaw mitâtaht ayiwâkês nipahêw mahîhkanah . Often he killed more than ten wolves in a day.
mihcêt osîhtâw cêsipicikanah , wiyâs êkotah êh-akotât , wiyâs êh-akotât cêsipicikanihk . He built many drying-frames, on which he hung his meat.
êkwah aw îskwêw âhkamêyimôw . The woman, too, worked bravely.
kêkâc wiyâpaniyik pôn-âtoskêw , mistay ê-atoskêcik . It would be almost dawn when they quit work, so busy were they.
âsay ati-kâ-kîsopwêyâyiw . The warm weather was already coming on.
maht êkwah nk-ôsîhâw otâpânâsk , itêyihtam . “I suppose I had better make a sled now,” he thought.
osîhêw atim-otâpânâskwah , êh-pasahwât mistikwah , napakitâpânâskwah êh-osîhât . He built a dog-sled with split trees, a flat dog-sled.
ê-kî-kîsihât , tahpotêw . When he had finished it, he tied it up. LB on {tahpotêw}: Probably {takohtêw}: “he came back to the house.”
êkotah napakâhtikohk ahêw mostoswêyânah mînah mahîhkaniwêyânah , nanâtohk atâwâkanah . On the boards of it he put buffalo-robes, wolfskins, and all kinds of furs.
sipwêhtêw , êy-itohtêt waskâhikanihk , otâtâwêwah ê-ntawâpamât . He went off to see the trader in his house.
takohtêw . He came there.
haw , pîhtokah ; asam kitêmak , itik okimâwah . “Well, bring them in; feed your dogs,” said the agent to him.
pîhtokahêw waskâhikanihk , êh-asamât . He brought them into the shed and fed them.

êkwah awa oskinîkiw kâ-kitimâkisit ,
awînah itah êh-ayât êh-pêw-âh-ohci-sipwêhtêyan ? itik . Then they asked the poor young man, “Who is there at the places you come from?”

seg.gloss: “Only my wife and I.

seg.q: mistahi nitayân wiyâs wiyinwah pimiyah atâwâkanak .
seg.gloss: I have a great deal of meat, fats, grease, and fur.
If you need meat, I can give you some.”
“Yes, I want all the food you have.
“How many wagonloads is it?”
“One, two, ten wagonloads.”
“Well! You are saying a great deal.

seg.q: ahpôh ôtênaw êy-otihtamân , nama wîhkâc mitâtaht sâkaskinêwak otâpânâskwak .
seg.gloss: Even when I come to a town, there are never ten loads.”
“Yes.”

seg.q: êkwah êh-pêyakoyan , kiwîkimâkan ê-nîsiyêk , mistahi kâ-ntawêyimacik otâpânâskwak .
seg.gloss: “For you and your wife alone that is quite a few sleds.”

p.seg:
êhag , itêw ,
nôhtaw . “Yes,” answered the other, “and that is not all.

seg.gloss: It is for meat alone that I need ten sleds.

seg.q: tahto kêkway atâwâkanah mêstawatâtwâwi kôskinîkîmak , êkoyikohk nka-pêy-itohtân ta-pêw-otinikêyân .
seg.gloss: When your helpers have carted away all the furs, then I shall come to take my pay.

seg.q: anohc wiyah pêyakwasâkay kika-miyin , kaskitêwêkin êkwah pêhpêsâpowêyân .
seg.gloss: Today just give me one dress-length, black cloth and striped cloth.

seg.q: êkwah kiyah ! pêyakwayôwinis wêmistikôsiw-ayôwinisah , astotin , êkwah kiyah kiminihkwêwin kâ-miywâsik , êkwah pêyakonisk mihkwêkin , êkwah cistêmâw ;
seg.gloss: And one suit of your white-man's clothes, a hat, and some of your own good liquor, one fathom of red flannel, and some tobacco;
that is all you need to give me.
When I come back to collect, I shall tell you the rest.”

p.seg: kîwêw . owîkimâkanah otihtêw . pêyakwâ nipâw ; owîkimâkanah otihtêw . He went home to his wife, sleeping one night on the way.
miyêw . He gave her the things.

seg.gloss: “Stick to your work;

p.seg: ômâ osihtâh kit-ôskotâkayin , itêw . make yourself a dress of this,” he told her.

kakwêyahôw ê-kaskikwâtahk aw îskwêw oskotâkay ôma kaskitêwêkin , otâsa mînah aw îskwêw , wanakwayah mînah . The woman worked busily, sewing a dress for herself out of the black broadcloth, as well as some gaiters and sleeves.
postayôwinisêw aw îskwêw . She put on her new clothes.

hâ , pakwahtêh ômah , itêw owîkimâkanah ,
ôma wâpowêyân . “Good, now wear this round your waist,” he said to his wife, “this robe.”

ê-kîsi-postayôwinisêt aw îskwêw , êkwah awa nâpêw postayôwinisêw , wêmistikôsiw-ayôwinisah ; astotin , postatotinêw . When the woman had dressed up, the man also dressed up in white-man's clothes, and put on his hat.
âsay namoya kitimâkisiwak . Now they were no longer poor.
otinam ; oyâkanihk iskotêwâpoy sîkinam , êkwah êyakô êh-minihkwêcik . He took the whiskey and poured it into a bowl and then they drank it.
kêkâc ê-wâpaniyik . When it was almost daylight, LB's translation merged into first sentence of next paragraph.

seg.gloss: “There, that will do; let us stop drinking;
we have too much work ahead;
some people are coming, Frenchmen, to fetch meat.
Set bravely to work.

seg.q: osâm mistahi kikitimâkisinânaw , êkâ awiyak êh-wahkomâyahk .
seg.gloss: We are altogether too poor, having no kinspeople.

seg.q: êwak ôhci kâ-kîh-atâwêyân atimwak , êwakonik kit-ôtêmiyahk .
seg.gloss: It was for this I bought the dogs, to be our beasts of burden.
Take heart and work bravely;
I too shall work stoutly at getting furs.”

p.seg: tâpwê ê-kî-nisto-tipiskâyik nikotwâsik otâpânâskwah takosiniyiwah . Accordingly, three days later six sleds arrived.

seg.gloss: “Bring only meat;

seg.q: atâwâkanak pêyak otâpânâsk ka-pêsiwâwâwak , niyânan otâpânâsk wiyâs êkwah .
seg.gloss: one load of fur you will bring, and five loads of meat.”

p.seg: êh-takosihkik ôkih wêmistikôsiwak , êkwah pôsihtâwak wiyâs ; When those Frenchmen arrived, they loaded meat;
namoya âpihtaw otinamwak ; namoya ahpôh âpihtaw atâwâkanah otinêwak . they did not take half of it, and they took not even half of the pelts.
kîwêwak . They went back.
êkwah nêtê waskâhikanihk takosinwak . They arrived yonder at the trading-house.
êkwah aw ôkimâw âcimostawâw : Then the agent was told:

seg.gloss: “Perhaps twenty sleds will be filled.

seg.q: mistahi wiyâs , pimiyah mînah , wiyinwah mînah .
seg.gloss: There is much meat, grease, and fat.

seg.q: mâskôc mistahê kik-êtêyihtên , okimâw , wâpahtamanê , pêyak ayîsiyiniw kita-miyisk ahtayah , nanâtohk mîciwin .
seg.gloss: No doubt you will think it a great deal for one man to give you in fur and various kinds of food.
He has grown rich, all by himself with his wife.

seg.q: mihtah êh-wîkicik tâpiskôc ôtênaw ayîsiyiniw wêtihtahkih .
seg.gloss: The firewood where they live looks like a town, as one approaches.

seg.q: namoya wîhkâc kahkiyaw sâkaskinêwak otâpânâskwak , êkwah oki nikotwâsik otâpânâskwak kahkiyaw kâ-sâkaskinêcik .
seg.gloss: Never are all the sleds full, and there are the six sleds all loaded.

seg.q: êkwah nânitaw nîsitanaw otâpânâskwak ta-sipwêhtêyân kahkiyaw nika-pêtân tahtoh kâ-ayâcik mîciwin ahtayah minah .
seg.gloss: If I go off with some twenty sleds, I can bring all the meat they have and the furs.”
“So that is the way you fared?”
“Yes.”
“You will go off with twenty sleds.

seg.q: kîspin sâkaskinêcih , kahkiyaw sâkaskinêtwâwih , tâpiskôc mihcêt otênawah êh-wâpahtamân nik-êtêyihtên .
seg.gloss: When they are all full, I shall think I am beholding many villages.
Very well, be off.”

p.seg: êkwa sipwêhtêwak nîsitanaw otâpânâskwak . So twenty sleds started out.

seg.gloss: “When you have loaded it all, let them set out and come here.
I should like to see his wife who does so much work.”

p.seg: takosinwak ; êkwah kahkiyaw otâpânâskwak sâkaskinayêwak . They arrived; and all the sleds were loaded full.
êkwah awah otêmah atimwah aw ôpwâsimôw ayênâniw kahkiyaw otâpahêw , atâwâkanah êh-pôsihât , êh-otâpêyit . In addition the Stony hitched up all his eight dogs and loaded the sled with fur and took it.
namoya sêmâk sipwêhtêw . He did not set out right away.
ê-kî-nisto-kîsikâyik sipwêhtêw ; otihtam waskâhikanah . After three days he set out; he came to the trading-post.

namêskwa kîsi-masinahikêwak , êh-akihtahkik wiyâs pimiyah kâhkêwakwah wiyinwah atâwâkanah , êyikohk êy-ispayiyik . They had not yet done writing as they counted the amount of the meat, grease, dried meat, fat, and pelts.
êh-takosihk , kêyâpic atoskêyiwah . When he arrived, they were still at work.
êh-takosihk , ohpâpêkipitamân kiskiwêhon . When he reached the place, they hoisted the flag for him.
pê-nakiskâk , ê-wîh-ati-pîhtokêt iskwâhtêmihk , êh-atamiskawât ôhi nâpêwah êkwah ôh îskwêwah . They came to meet him, and as he entered the door, he shook hands with the man and his wife.
êh-atamiskawât , êkoyikohk kâ-matwêwiwik misi-pâskisikan . As he shook hands with them, the cannon was fired.

êkosi ,
ây , êkwah kêkway kintawêyihtên ? itik . Then, “Well, and what do you wish for?” he was asked.

seg.q: hâ , kiyah kitayôwinisah nêwôh ayôwinisah ayîsiyiniwak ta-posiskahkik ê-kaskitêwâkih .
seg.gloss: “Of your clothes, four suits for men to wear, black suits.
And, if you have one, a horse.
That is what I want.”

p.seg: êhag , ntayâwâw pêyak , itik ôh ôkimâwah ; “Very well, I have one,” the agent told him;

seg.gloss: “tomorrow they will be brought.”

p.seg: êkwah ê-wâpaniyik mênikanihk pîhtokêtisahomâwah pôtih mihcêt misatimwah . And in the morning, there, into the paddock were driven a great many horses.

âw , itik ,
âstam , itik okimâwah ; “Well,” said the other to him, “Come here,” said the agent;
pê-wâpam awa misatim , itik . “Come and look at this horse,” he said.
itohtêw ; wâpamêw pôtih mihcêt misatimwah . He went there; there he saw many horses.

êkwah awaw okimâw ayênâniw ayâwêw atimwah , itêyihtam ,
aw okimâw . “So the chief has eight horses,” thought he.

â , itik ,
ôki misatimwak têpakohp kik-ôtinâwak . “There,” he told him, “you may take seven of these horses.”
êkwah otinêw ; têpakohp misatimwah êkwah otinêw êyakonih . He took them; he took seven of those horses.

seg.q: haw , pêyak kâ-nitômat misatim , wiyâs kâ-miyiyin .
seg.gloss: “Now you asked for one horse for the meat you gave me.

seg.q: êkoyikô têpipayiw wiyâs , ôkih misatimwak kâ-otinacik .
seg.gloss: That meat pays for these horses you have just taken.

p.seg: hâw , kitatamiskâtin ; niya nitêm kimiyitin , êh-atamiskâtân , itêw ; And now I want to make you a present; I give you my own horse as a present,” he told him;

seg.q: mistahê kitôtên , tâpiskôc niyânan ôtênawah êw-otihtamân , iyikohk kâ-miyiyin mîciwin ahtayak mînah .
seg.gloss: “You have done great things; as if I came to five villages is the amount of the food and the pelts you have given me.

seg.q: êwak ohci namoya kika-nêpêwisin , têkosiniyin ôtah .
seg.gloss: Therefore you shall not need to be bashful when you come here.

seg.q: kiya nîkân kik-âtamiskâtin , namoya kotak awiyak , kiya pikôw .
seg.gloss: I shall greet you first of all, no one else, only you.

seg.q: pêyak okimâwayân kimiyitin . pêyak kiskiwêhon kimiyitin .
seg.gloss: A chief's coat I shall give you, and a flag;
these I give you as presents.
So much for that.
And now, what will you take in the way of clothes?”
“Suits for four men.
Also some of your liquor.

seg.q: êkwah mihkwêkin nêwonisk êkwah kaskitêwêkin nêwinisk .
seg.gloss: Also four fathoms of red flannel, and four of black broadcloth.
Also some tobacco.
Also ammunition.
Also various things, such as mirrors and paint.
That is the number of things.”

p.seg: kahkiyaw miyâw . He was given all of it.
nâtakâm itohtêw , ê-ntawi-kîskikahahk apasoyah . He went into the forest and cut tent-sticks.

mitâtaht ayiwâk têpakohp pêtâw apasoyah , ê-kî-pêtât êkwah kâ-miyiht ayôwinisah tahtoh kâ-ntotahk , cistêmâwah , mînah kahkiyaw kêkway kâ-miyiht awâ kâ-kitimâkisit . he brought seventeen tentpoles along with the things he had been given, the clothes he had asked for, the tobacco, and all the things he had been given, that poor man.
kîwêw ; otihtam wîkiwâw . He went home; he reached their dwelling.
âsay iyihtêyiw ; miyoskamiyiw . It was already the time of thaw; spring had come.
êkwah tâpwêy êkwah nôcihêw mostoswah . Then accordingly he hunted buffalo.
kiyipah nipahêw . Quickly did he kill them.
nîsosâp êkwah osihtâw aw îskwêw pahkêkinwah ; kîsihtâw . Then the woman prepared twelve hides; she finished them.
êkwah kaskikwâtamwak , mîkiwâhp êw-osîhtâcik . Then they sewed them, making a tent.
êkwah cîkâskwahpitamwak ômâ mihkwêkin mîna ôma kaskitêwêkin . they tied that red cloth and black cloth to the poles.
êkwah otâkosiniyiw ; êkoyikohk kîsi-nahastâsôw . When night fell, he had finished arranging his belongings.
êkwah êh-pîhtokêcik apiwak . Then they went into the tent and sat there.
postayôwinisêh , itêw owîkimâkanah . “Put on your good clothes,” he told his wife.
postayôwinisêw aw îskwêw , awa mîna nâpêw . The woman dressed up, and so did the man.
êkwah mînah minihkwêwak ômah iskotêwâpoy . Then they drank that whiskey.

kêkâc ê-wâpaniyik ,
âh , pôni-minihkwêtân , itêw owîkimâkanah . When it was almost daybreak, “Now, let us stop drinking,” he said to his wife.

êh-wâpaniyik ,
âh , êkwah ka-picinânaw ; ka-ntônawânawak ayîsiyiniwak , itêw owîkimâkanah . At daybreak, “There, now we shall move camp; we shall look for some people,” he said to her.
êkwah piciwak . So they moved camp.
tahto-kîsikâw pimipiciwak . All day long they marched.
âskaw minahôw , mîciwin êy-osihtâcik pahkêkin mînah . At times he killed game, and they prepared stored food and hides.
kêtahtawê êh-kîsopwêyik wâpahtamwak mîkiwâhpah pôtih . Then, when the heat of the day had come, they saw some tents.
âh , ayôwêpitân ôtah , itêw wîwa awa kâ-kîhkitimâkisit . “Well, let us stop and rest here,” said he who had been poor to his wife.
kîtahtawê kâ-wâpamâcik êh-têhtapiyit , ispatinâhk êh-ayâyit . Presently they saw a man on horseback, on a hill.
wâpamon otinam ê-wâsâpiskinamôwât . He took a mirror and flashed signals to him.
itohtêw aw oskinîkiw . The young man approached.

hâh , awa êh-takosihk aw ôskinîkiw , êh-kitâpamât ,
êyôkw âwa kâh-kîh-kitimâkisit , itêyihtam . When this young man looked at them, “This is he who once was poor,” was his thought.

êkosi mâka êyakô êkwah kakwêcimâw ,
êkotah ciy ayâw anah kâ-kîh-mânah-wîkihkêmowak ? Thereupon that man asked him, “Is he over there with whom I used to stay?”

seg.gloss: “Yes, he is there.”
“And he from whom I bought the dogs?”
“Yes, he is there.”
“And the chief from whom I bought tanning implements?”
“Yes, he is over there.”
“And the chief from whom I bought a gun?”
“He is over there.
All the people are over there.”
“Very well, ride back.

seg.q: êwakonik aniki nêwo anik ôkimâwak kita-pêy-itohtêwak ôtah , ôm êtah k-âyiwêpiyân .
seg.gloss: Let those four chiefs come here where I am halting.”
“Yes.”

p.seg: êkâya mâka kotak awiyak kita-pêy-itohtêw ; êwakonik pikô êkwah kiyah , itêw . “But let no one else come here; only they and you,” he told him.

seg.gloss: “Yes.”

p.seg: sipwêhtêw ; kîwêpayiw ; kahkiyaw nêwô ntomêw ôh ayîsiyiniwah . He went away; he rode back; he called all four of those men.

seg.q: nêmah k-ôsêhcâk , k-âwâsitêk nêma , êkotê êh-ohcih-ntomikawiyêk .
seg.gloss: “Yonder hill, just beyond it, that is from where the invitation comes to you.”

p.seg: hâ , êkosi têhtapiwak êh-ispayicik . Accordingly they mounted and rode to that place.
otihtêwak ôhi ka-kitimâkisiyit . They came to that man who had been poor.
mâmaskâtêwak . They wondered at him.
mistahê ê-kih-kitimâkisit awa k-êsinâkosit kâ-wêyôtisit , itêyihtamwak ôk ôkimâwak nêwô . “He who was so very poor, here he is looking like this, a wealthy man,” thought those four chiefs.
otinam ayôwinisah . He took the clothes.
ôhi postayôwinisê , itêw ôh ôkimâwah . “Do you wear these,” he said to that chief.
êkwah pêyakonisk cistêmâw miyêw . He gave him also a fathom's length of twist tobacco.

seg.gloss: “Here is smoking-stuff.

p.seg: kitatamihin ê-kîh-miyiyan ôkih atimwak , itêw . I thank you for having given me these dogs,” he said to him.
êkwah kotak . Then another.
ayôwinisah miyêw , mihkihkwanah iskwêw-âpacihcikanah kâ-kîh-atâmât . He gave him clothing from whom he had bought hide-scrapers and other women's utensils.

hâw , ôhi postayôwinisê , êh-miyât , êkwah pêyakonisk cistêmâw ,
awa pîhtwâkan , itêw . “Now, take these to wear,” and he gave them to him, together with a fathom's length of tobacco; “Here is something to smoke,” he told him.
êkwah kotakah otinam . Then he took some more.
âcimostawêw tanisi kâ-tôtahk . He told them how he had done.

seg.q: anohc kâ-piponiyik kîh-kîsihtâwâw êwakôw oma kê-wâpahtamêk ôhi êkwah kâ-miyitakok .
seg.gloss: “This winter I have paid him for all this which you see here, and these things which I have given you.
seg.note: LB on {kîh-kîsihtâwâw}: Wrongly recorded; probably I overheard the prefix {ni-}: “I”.

seg.gloss: He called me 'Chief.'”
“So be it; you shall be chief.

p.seg: tahtoh kâ-tipêyihtamân mîkiwâhpah kahkiyaw kimiyitin , ta-tipêyihtaman , itik kahkiyaw ôhi nêwô okimâwah . As many tents as are under me, I give them all to you to command,” he was told by each of those four chiefs.
êkwah ispiciw . Then he moved camp to that place.

êw-otihtahk ê-wîhkwêstêyikih mîkiwâhpah , pîhtêyisk ntawi-manokêyiwa ôh ôkimâwa , êh-atoskâkot . When he came to where the tents stood in a circle, those chieftains set up a lodge in the center, doing the work for him.
osâm mistah ê-kî-kitimâkisit mâskôc mistahê k-ôh-okimâwit , k-oh-atoskêt . No doubt it was because he had been so poor, that he became chief, that he worked.
êkosi kahkiyaw . That is all.
